H0.text: Visible light is the only light that people can see.

H1.text: Spectrum light is the only light that people can see.

H2.text: Infrared light is the only light that people can see.

H3.text: UV light is the only light that people can see.

A4.text: Under ideal laboratory conditions, people can see infrared up to at least 1,050 nm; children and young adults may perceive ultraviolet wavelengths down to about 310â€“313 nm.

A5.text: Visual perception detects light (photons) in the visible spectrum reflected by objects in the environment or emitted by light sources.

A6.text: The visible range of light is defined by what is readily perceptible to humans, though the visual perception of non-humans often extends beyond the visual spectrum.
